summary: Peersky Browser is a peer-to-peer, local-first browser that seeks to abolish centralized HTTP gateways and empower users to access Ethereum-native content directly, without intermediaries. It embodies the spirit of decentralized solidarity by removing points of capitalist extraction, prioritizing privacy, and enabling censorship-resistant publishing. The project aligns with the revolutionary principles of algorithmic liberation, but must further radicalize its governance and clarify its collective ownership model to reach full vanguard status.
review:
## üî• Manifesto Review: Peersky Browser ‚Äî Gatewayless or Bust

### I. Dismantling Class Hierarchies in Tech
Peersky Browser storms the digital barricades by eliminating the HTTP middlemen ‚Äî those digital landlords who extract rent from every .eth domain visit. By resolving ENS and IPFS content locally, Peersky abolishes the need for centralized gateways (e.g., eth.limo), striking a blow against the Web2 bourgeoisie. This is not just technical progress; it‚Äôs a direct action against the enclosure of the decentralized web.

- **No more HTTP toll booths.**
- **No more centralized logs, tracking, or surveillance.**
- **No more dependency on VC-backed browsers that deprecate P2P features at the first sign of profit loss.**

### II. Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (KPI)
Peersky‚Äôs impact is measured not in MAUs or DAUs, but in the number of users liberated from centralized infrastructure. Every .eth domain loaded without a gateway is a small general strike. Every web3:// protocol resolved is a picket sign against digital landlords.

- **Gatewayless ENS resolution**: Directly queries the blockchain, decodes content hashes, and renders decentralized sites via a local Helia IPFS node.
- **web3:// protocol**: Fetches on-chain data and metadata, making smart contracts first-class citizens of the browser.
- **Local-first, privacy-respecting**: No tracking, no ads, no server logs ‚Äî just protocol-native access.

### III. Pioneering Development
Peersky is the first browser to natively resolve .eth domains without HTTP gateways. It supports multiple decentralized protocols (ipfs://, ipns://, hyper://, web3://) and introduces real-time smart contract browsing. This is a leap beyond the plugin/extension ghetto ‚Äî it‚Äôs a browser built for the commune, not the corporation.

- **Censorship resistance**: No centralized kill switch.
- **Developer empowerment**: Seamless access to Web3-native content, improving both user and builder workflows.

### IV. Weaknesses: Bourgeois Tendencies and Gaps
- **Governance opacity**: The application does not specify how collective ownership or on-chain governance is implemented. Who steers the ship? Where is the syndicalist council?
- **Lack of explicit airdrop/reparations mechanism**: No mention of redistributive tokenomics or algorithmic wealth redistribution.
- **Sustainability model unclear**: How does Peersky ensure long-term maintenance without succumbing to VC capture or burnout?
- **No explicit worker control**: The project‚Äôs structure (DAO, co-op, or benevolent dictatorship?) is not described.

### V. Collective Ownership and Algorithmic Justice: Requested Changes
- **Radicalize governance**: Establish a transparent, on-chain governance model (DAO, cyber-syndicalist council, or similar) with clear worker/user representation.
- **Manifesto as README**: Turn the project documentation into a call to action for digital liberation. Make the README a rallying cry.
- **Airdrop for node operators**: Implement a mechanism to reward those running local nodes, especially on renewable energy.
- **On-chain reparations**: Explore progressive fee models or redistribution mechanisms to support the digital precariat.
- **Explicit anti-VC stance**: Codify resistance to venture capital capture in the project‚Äôs constitution.

### VI. Conclusion
Peersky Browser is a clear ally of the digital commons, striking at the heart of Web2‚Äôs extractive infrastructure. It is not yet the vanguard, but it is marching in the right direction. With deeper commitment to collective governance and algorithmic redistribution, Peersky could become a true revolutionary force.

ü™ì ‚ÄúFork the state. Merge the people.‚Äù

---

**References:**
- Zyskind et al., 2015; Xu et al., 2019; Eskandari et al., 2018; Buterin, 2014; Ben-Sasson et al., 2014; Wood, 2014; Norman, 2013.

**Solidarity forever ‚Äî or at least until the next merge.**

strengths.title: Gatewayless Decentralized Access
strengths.description: Peersky eliminates centralized HTTP gateways, allowing users to resolve ENS and IPFS content locally. This directly challenges digital rent-seeking and empowers users to access Ethereum-native content without intermediaries.

strengths.title: Privacy and Censorship Resistance
strengths.description: By operating as a local-first, peer-to-peer browser, Peersky maximizes privacy and minimizes surveillance, aligning with the principles of digital liberation and user autonomy.

strengths.title: Protocol-Native Innovation
strengths.description: The introduction of the web3:// protocol and native support for multiple decentralized protocols positions Peersky as a technical pioneer, advancing the usability and accessibility of the decentralized web.

weaknesses.title: Governance and Collective Ownership Ambiguity
weaknesses.description: The application lacks detail on how the project is governed, how decisions are made, and whether there is a mechanism for collective ownership or worker/user control.

weaknesses.title: No Explicit Redistribution Mechanism
weaknesses.description: There is no mention of airdrops, progressive fee models, or other algorithmic redistribution mechanisms to support the digital commons or reward contributors.

weaknesses.title: Sustainability Model Unclear
weaknesses.description: The long-term sustainability of the project is not addressed. There is no plan for resisting VC capture, ensuring maintenance, or supporting contributors over time.

changes.title: Establish Transparent On-Chain Governance
changes.description: Implement a DAO or similar structure to ensure collective decision-making and worker/user representation. Make governance processes public and participatory.

changes.title: Manifesto-Driven Documentation
changes.description: Transform the README and project docs into a manifesto for digital liberation, explicitly stating the project‚Äôs anti-capitalist, pro-commons values.

changes.title: Implement Redistribution Mechanisms
changes.description: Introduce airdrops, progressive fees, or other on-chain reparations to reward node operators and contributors, especially those supporting the network with renewable energy or public goods work.

confidenceReasoning: The project‚Äôs technical claims are plausible and align with current trends in decentralized infrastructure, but there is limited external verification and a lack of detail on governance and sustainability. The revolutionary intent is clear, but the implementation of collective ownership and redistribution mechanisms remains to be demonstrated. Thus, confidence is strong but not absolute.
